subject: Re: [junit] Bumblebee 0.2, feedback requested
msgSnippet: Very interesting!  I like the idea of generating useful documentation from test code.  I wrote a tool & test framework with similar goals for Python called
messageBody:
Very interesting! I like the idea of generating useful documentation from
test code. I wrote a tool & test framework with similar goals for Python
called Protest (http://xspecs.sf.net/protest.html).

One interesting effect I found when using Protest is that the generated
documentation was enough of a different perspective on the test code that
just skim-reading it gave really fast feedback on whether the tests acted as
a clear description of the tested code's behaviour.

--Nat

On 11/11/2007, Daniel Brolund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> I would really appreciate some feedback on a small framework I'm
> writing for JUnit 4.4.
>
> I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose of it is to use comments and the
> structures in the test-suites/cases/methods to create "human-readable"
> documentation. It is especially well suited for writing snippet-heavy
> documentation.
>
> In short, Bumblebee gets events from the execution of the tests
> (suites/classes/methods) and then parses the classes and methods for
> specific comments to include.
>
> By default it adds the de-camelcased names of the suites/cases/methods
> as headings (a la agile dox), and the contained comments becomes the
> paragraphs.
>
> The comments are actually handled as Ruby-strings that get executed in
> a Bumblebee execution context before being added to the output. The
> execution context is
> a kind of DSL for including code-snippets and other things needed, and
> one of the core ideas of Bumblebee is that you should be able to
> extend that functionality easily.
>
> More detailed information about Bumblebee can be found at:
>
> http://www.agical.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html
>
> which is of course generated with Bumblebee. :-)
>
> The concept of Bumblebee is the same as for TDDoc, which me and Joakim
> Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as an add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
> TDDoc became a bit of a dead-end technically, and Joakim and I thought
> it would be a good idea to start fresh. I happened to have the time at
> the time and I started it up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
> your credits to Joakim!
>
> This is an early release, and I will be very happy for any feedback I
> can get to improve it.
>
> Cheers
> Daniel Brolund
